Sorry I'm so late. To answer your question about its resistance to being melted, you'll have to stop thinking in terms of chemistry and get more into physics. Some folks here are close but not quite.

The microstructures of the lead and zinc compounds are arranged in such a way as to form something akin to a coal miner's lamp. They use a tightly woven cage to contain a flame to provide light but doesn't ignite the surrounding air that would sometimes be filled with coal dust and other flammable particulates. This design is what's used to form the flameholder in a jet engine and the bottom surface of the space shuttles.

These work by having any heat directed to them drawn away from any part of the cage to another cooler part that's larger in area. This allows for a dissipation of heat that is faster than the rate of heating at that particular point. And while there are limits to this bleeding of heat, this effect does keep the material cool enough not to melt while tanking lots of heat to the point of radiating light. In fact, NASA has a video that shows a very similar lighting pattern with the stuff they use for the space shuttle.

As for why it loses that resistance after the zinc is gone, the structure has changed to the point that heat can't flow as easily so dissipation gives way to absorption. Whatever matrix that was formed , it had to have been either highly crystalline or at least dentrite-like in nature. That's the only way any of it would work.

My thoughts on the drying issue:
When it is first prepared, there is water separating the individual strands. This allows the strands to easily move past each other making it soft.
When you dry it, regardless of how, as the water evaporates, surface tension pulls the strands together and causes them to contact each other all along the strand.
This prevents the strands from moving easily moving past each other making it a hard/brittle structure.
When you try to re-wet it, the strands are already in contact and don't want to leave.

There's something that happens to plant roots that might explain why you can't respongify it after its dried.

When you take a cutting from a plant and put it in water to grow roots, a very fine network of hair-like roots fans out in the water to maximize surface area.

It's difficult to transplant a water rooted plant into dirt, because when you pull the roots out of the water they all clump together because of the surface tension of water, and they don't spread back out when you plant it in dirt. New roots have to grow to replace the ones that are stuck together.

When you dry out the sponge, all of the very delicate suspended filaments of crystals get tangled into a crystal-like matrix as the water leaves and eventually they lock together when dry. Rehydrating it doesn't untangle the knots

I think that maybe the chemical differences between zinc and lead are having an effect here. Firstly, this is based on considering the possibility that your torch flame is actually CREATING the oxides as you are trying to melt the sponges, simply because heat increases the reaction rates. Maybe pure(ish) lead melts before it oxidizes under the flame, but zinc, which not only has a higher melting point but I think is also more reactive with oxygen, usually oxidizes before it melts. It's also worth noting that ZnO is BY FAR the most refractory substance likely to be involved here, being solid at temperatures where all the other likely compounds would be gasses:

Pb(CH3COO)2: decomposes 510 K
Pb(CH3COO)2: melts 553 K
ZnCl2: melts 563 K, boils 1005 K
PbCO3: decomposes 588 K
Pb: melts 601 K, boils 2202 K
Zn: melts 693 K, boils 1180 K
PbCl2: melts 774 K, boils 1220 K
Pb3O4: decomposes by ~800 K
PbO: melts 1161 K, boils 1750 K
ZnO: decomposes 2247 K

Regarding point 1: The lead sponge likely has a much lower thermal conductivity. Thus, where a solid block of lead would conduct heat away from the heat source, the lead sponge would likely have a steeper heat gradient, allowing some areas to melt while others stay relatively cool.

Regarding point 3: As stated above, the lead sponge likely has a much lower thermal conductivity. It seems plausible that the heated portions might reach a temperature that allows the metal to burn, especially since the portions of the sponge not directly heated are not cooling the sponge. This is specific to the fresh lead-zinc sponge specifically, because the other test had the sponge possibly oxidise before being heated, leading to a different melting point.

Regarding point 5: There are two mechanisms that might have caused the sponge to not become soft after being placed in water, at least in your experimental setup. The first might be whatever causing the reaction when in air causing either a structural or chemical change in the sponge. The second might be the rapid recompression under the water causing a structural change. You might wish to air-dry the sponge under nitrogen gas; this would exclude both the potential structural and chemical changes, leaving only the "water not properly reentering" interpretation.

Regarding drying under a vacuum: a rapid recompression would probably cause the water pressure to rapidly compress and hence damage the sponge; perhaps a more slow recompression might better preserve the sponge. If the sponge is more soggy after a slower recompression, the rapid recompression might be linked to irreversible structural changes in the sponge.

At the most extreme, replacing the water in the sponge with supercritical fluid would probably successfully preserve the sponge structure, leaving some sort of lead aerogel.

The drying process might not be irreversible.

if you are right about the formation of led microfibers then these would initially be highly pure. before drying the microfibers are spaced out with water. when the water is removed the fibers can be in closer contact. this would be very small scale movement not noticeable at a macro scale. with the fibers in closer contact they can corrode together (like a nut and bolt rusting together) or if there is no air they can cold weld together. I think lead can cold weld.

on macro scales, cold welding usually is achieved with high pressure, and it is important to have the surfaces perfectly clean.

with the incredible cleanliness of newly formed lead crystals a small fraction of them might be able to cold weld on contact, each weld would be incredibly week but there are huge numbers of overlapping fibers to form bonds.

when rehydrated those fibers that were either welded or corroded into a single piece cannot be lubricated by the water and do not move, there is more corrosion in air than cold welding in its absence and that is why the sample dehydrated under vacuum was softer when rehydrated.

Answers, As i see them:
1. Zinc chloride is acting as a flux. it has a melting point of 290 C so... That's why your melting point decreased from pure lead. Lead tetrachloride has an even lower temperature (50C) so... something to be mindful of.
2. Mmm.... I would think it's a result of the chlorine impurity, although, to be honest, i don't see a pure purple flame. I see a flame that shows a reducing carbon flame combining with a hot hydrogen flame. The color is being swirled together because of the force of the torch. spectral analysis needs a proper prism though to be accurate.
3. Water adsorption. High surface area materials hold onto water, which then alters the chemistry of reactions occuring near it.
4. Zinc chloride. it's not the zinc alone. It's both the chlorine and the zinc.
5. The lead sponge and the zinc network have fuzed. Probably through the action of Lead oxide with zinc (acetate/chloride), with some sort of ionic salt intermediate.
6. it's an electrochemical reaction. You probably could reverse it if you were pumping the sponge with electrons while also putting it under vacuum.
7. The water probably could get back in, but the issue is that either the lead or the zinc is missing electrons and in an ionic state at that point. ionic compounds are rigid and brittle.

The wet sponge has an ultra high surface area and is composed mostly of lead and zic metals. When dried in an inert atmosphere, the surface tension of the water grabs on to the metal particles and permanently destroys the fine structure that makes it soft, it may also cold-weld some of the lead particles together. This is very similar to the problem of making aerogels, you pretty much need to make the wet gel/sponge form, then do a supercritical fluid extraction process to get rid of the liquid inside the pores without the surface tension and viscosity of the liquid destroying them. If you take the dry sponge out of the inert gas, oxygen rapidly oxidizes the vast majority of the lead and zinc content, leading to heating and a bunch of lead and zinc compounds that are hard and crumbly. Same happens when you dry it in air. The acid treatment dissolves the zinc oxide, making it easier to melt.

I used to work on porous materials and, generally speaking, drying a porous network will collapse it due to high surface tension in the pores. There are two ways around this: Either use supercritical drying, or do a surface treatment to decrease the affinity of the material to the solvent. Ohterwise you're going to end up with all the large pores collapsing and only micropores left.

I did my best to answer all the questions.

1.) Why does the acid treated pre-dried sponge have such a low meltion point? It appears to melt even easier than elemental lead. Lead Dioxide Melting Point: 290 °C (554 °F) <---Lower melting point than lead.

Lead
Melting Point: 327.46 °C (​621.43 °F)

Lead (II) Oxide
Melting Point: 888 °C (1,630 °F)

2.) Where did the purple flame come from in the first couple tests? Band gap energy / intervalence charge transfer between specific lead and zinc ion valence states. (Ti IV and Fe II ions exhibit this behavior in sapphire as the intervalence charge transfer shifts Ti Ti IV to Ti III, and Fe II to Fe III.) This produces a characteristic absorption in the electromagnetic spectrum.


3.) Why doesn't the fresh lead and zinc sponge melt, and instead light on fire? Zinc and lead have a high affinity for each other and easily form an alloy that is difficult to separate without high temperatures. (see the Imperial Smelting Process)


4.) Why does treating it with acid allow it to melt? Does the zinc have some sort of role to play in this? Superficially it does as the acid penetration does leach out a fair amount of zinc, but the zinc and lead are still alloyed together since total dissolution at high temperatures did not take place.


5.) Putting it back into water doesn't seem to make it soft again, so what is going on? The oxides form a less malleable / more rigid structure engulfing the entire sponge surface of the alloy. Since the zinc and lead are not in stoichiometric proportions in solution, there is an abundance of lead which allows it to initially be soft/malleable. Once dried, the oxides form a passivation layer and at the elemental/molecular level the lead and zinc have also had more time to form it's own crystalline structure as an alloy.


6.) Why does the drying process seem to be irreversible, even when oxygen and CO2 are excluded? It's incredibly difficult to separate the zinc from the lead due to the affinity for each other, so it's still an alloy of the two elements. If you bring it to a high enough temperature in an oxygen free / inert atmosphere, then you can vaporize the zinc leaving almost pure lead behind. This is the reason borax flux works to purify elemental lead so well.

7.) Did it change structurally as it dried, or was the water just not able to get back in or something. The oxides form a crystalline layer covering the elemental and/or alloy of the zinc and lead so water shouldn't have any effect once reintroduced. Zinc is a lot more reactive than lead, but since they readily form an alloy, the molecular structure is a variable mix of the lead and zinc alloys as well as the oxides.

My reply is just on recovery yield from a metallurgical perspective, so I don't really address any of your questions:
I had created a piece of lead sponge by two different methods. The first being with zinc and I got the same results on part of it under the blow torch. I then used boric acid and covered the remaining dried sponge. The boric acid is used as a flux to protect the lead from oxidizing from heating, and it also allows other contaminates to leach out of the molten lead. The zinc ions and some lead gets into the flux and will form yellow and orange colored oxides in some of the bubbles on the flux/slag.

Once cooled you can break the flux away from the lead ingot. The next time you melt the lead, very little oxide will form on the surface and is virtually zinc free.

The other method I used to form a tree of Saturn was strictly with electrolysis, forming lead dendrites on the carbon cathode. It was just as amazing, if not more, than the zinc method. The advantage is that there is no zinc contamination, so just use boric acid or just borax as a flux and you'll lose very little lead through oxidation. The flux breaks free from pounding the lead bead on an anvil/flat chunk of metal and a hammer. You can recover very close to a theoretical 100% yield. I got >96%.

As a side note:
*The borax / boric acid works very well on bismuth recovery too. I achieved approximately 3.4 grams from a 350mL bottle of max strength liquid Pepto with 1050mg per dose. Approximately 1/3 of the bismuth subsalicylate is actually bismuth. (Bismuth Subsalicylate 12,306mg total (1040mg per 30mL in 355mL bottle)) Theoretical 100% yield: 4.1g. I got 83% and I imagine the majority of the loss to the coffee filters and anything that remains in this perfectly clear liquid in this mason jar I kept, still sitting on my window sill.

My general impressions would be as follows:

1.) The sponge is covered with an oxide layer. What little metal there is clings to this and cannot form large metal droplets. This also acts to insulate the rest of the sponge. You can see a similar effect with slag, especially lead slag and the spongy lead you get in some car batteries. In fact I've found about the only way I can get lead out of such slag is to reduce the oxide in some way, and it can be remarkable how much metal gets irretrievably bound up in it. (Worse though is aluminum slag, at least in my experience, maybe because the metal is less dense.)

2.) The yellow\orange flame I an get, either carbon or sodium which are EVERYWHERE. The purple naively looks like potassium, but that makes no sense. Maybe some weird molecular species?

3.) WATER. Dear LORD water. Have you ever dropped water onto hot zinc powder? Boom! Aluminum too. That stuff is hydric acid and packed a LOT more densely than atmospheric oxygen. Just try heat wet zinc powder as a comparison. That sort of stuff is dangerous.

4.) My guess here would be that the acid strips away the oxide layer; if an acid treated sponge were again toaster dried, how would that react? Is the change permanent or does some time standing in air negate this? The sponge is evidently VERY reactive if it can start steaming in air.

5.) The strands of metal are getting tangled. You'll see this with a lot of plastics such as PVA; they'll start out dispersed in water (Or another solvent) but will get hard on drying as the strands pull together and tangle. Then adding water doesn't reverse the change since the structure itself has altered. You might try hot water but I doubt that will have much effect either.

6.) The drying process seems to take some time, and the sponge again is VERY reactive. What happens when you use a solvent like alcohol to displace the water then dry THAT?That should minimize the time the metal will be able to react with water and oxygen.

7.) Answered above. I think there's a structural change going on.

the surface tension of water during drying can actually exert surprisingly large forces on fine particulate matter. For example when clay dries it shrinks significantly as the tiny particles are pulled together. My hypothesis is that the initial formation of the sponge is incomplete, and there are voids with finer pieces of lead 'suspended' loosely within them, with water lubricating them. When drying occurs these finer pieces cake onto the larger joined pieces forming a more structurally stable mass. Finally when the pieces are all caked together, vacuum welding or chemical oxidation causes them to be bound together tightly making the mass rigid.

It is composed of very small particles held togheter by friction forces (like you said in the video), but IMO the water is trapped between these particles when they are formed, acting like a lubricant which reduce the friction, so the particles can move relative to each other. As we know, if the particles forming a body can move realtive to each other, that body is malleable. After the water is evaporated, the particles come into contact, the friction forces become much stronger, and the sponge becomes solid. Finally, the water cannot re-enter between the lead particles after they come into contact, so the sponge stays solid.

Very little zinc in that original blob -- I doubt it's structural either, just a network of lead flakes smooshed together. There will be some leftover (on the order of 10% or less?), and the bubbling in acid proves this nicely.

Acid probably got rid of all the zinc, leaving lead metal and salts. First melt: must've been pretty clean and porous metal, hence oxidizing to yellow lead oxide readily. Note: zinc oxide is also yellow, when hot; white when cold (it's thermochromic).

Second melt: probably a lot of lead chloride present, acting as a flux. Flame color looks lead-like.

Third melt: the metal should coalesce at the bottom, but if it's really fine it may be left as drops. Seems to be the case. There is probably very little zinc present, as zinc chloride decomposes on heating, not melting very much.

By the way, the inner cone of the torch is fuel-air mixture that has not yet ignited. As you can see, IT IS VERY COLD! The hottest part of the flame is at the tip of the inner cone. The color of this cone also relates to mixture: neutral is a slightly light blue, rich is greenish, lean is violet (can be difficult to see, as the flame blows out when too lean). It can be hard to tell on camera, but it looks like the flame was neutral to reducing, which is fine.

You're definitely getting a lot of reaction with air. If you can prepare apparatus for heating under inert gas or vacuum, you should see very different behavior. Alternately, use a molten salt bath (but, beware of combining anything the least bit moist, and molten salts!). This is difficult for lead, as you need a mixture of inert chlorides (mostly alkali and alkaline earths) to get a eutectic melting low enough. Probably something in the NaCl-CaCl2-PbCl2 system would work very nicely.

Incidentally, lead and zinc are immiscible liquids (indeed, there's a silver extraction process, for use with Ag-rich Pb ores, that's basically a metal-phase Soxhlet extractor!), though they will stick together well enough in molten form to fool the eye. Once you get a solid pellet, you should be able to peel them apart and see this. (There will still be some of one dissolved in the other, as the solubility isn't zero.)

HTH!

Three tips for heating the lead sponge
First, be wary of heating zinc!!! Lead as well but not as dangerous. Metal fume fever has killed many welders and blacksmiths!

Second, pull the torch back a bit. You want the tip of the blue flame to barely touch the material.

And thirdly, invest in soft fire brick. It catches the heat and reflects it back into the material.

My thoughts on No.4 - why does acid help the foam melt easier? Well, the HCL would at least partly dissolve any oxides as they form. This keeps the lead surface clean of oxides, and helps the tiny fibres to sinter together into a melt. A reducing acid works even better, like ascorbic or formic acid. Organic acids are actually used in industry for this purpose, where they're known as a class of 'sintering aids' which allow metal parts to be sintered from metal powder without the use of an inert or reducing gas atmosphere.

proposed answers to some of the questions:
1) while melting it looked like it was a mixture of hydrated salts which often have a relatively low melting point. for example, anhydrous sodium sulfate has a melting point of 884 C and the decahydrate form has a melting point of 32 C
3) the high surface area of the zinc particles allow them to over heat and catch fire before they coalesce into droplets. the finely divided zinc oxide will prevent the lead from coalesce and it will oxidize as well.
4) without the zinc, the lead is able to melt and coalesce before being oxidized.

1) The acid dissolves some oxide coating on both metals to form Pb and Zn, and changes the overall metal composition. This change in metal composition results in a change in melting point and the formation of a eutectic (tl;dr alloys have lower melting points sometimes, kind of like azeotropes in distillation).

2) Potassium impurities are the simplest explanation, but I have no clue. It may be a result of the metals giving off a combination of different flame colors.

3) 14:50 The porous sponge is less thermally conductive because of the formation of convection currents within the air pockets of the sponge, so it didn't melt but instead reacted with heat (this is the basis on why aerogel and styrofoam are such good thermal insulators). The air bubbles were isolated from each other because this time the sponge was not treated with acid (allowing the currents to form and insulate, unlike in the other runs), and because it had not dried there was still fresh lead that was not covered in an oxide coating. This combination of high surface area and fresh exposed lead is also what lead to its rapid oxidation, as shown by the sparking and brilliant flame released.

4) Treatment with acid dissolves the oxide coating, which prevents the metal from melting by being a thermal insulator and having a high melting point as an ionic salt.

5) When the sponge is exposed to air, its high surface area causes its oxidation to be faster than normal, so an oxide forms such that the water cannot penetrate the oxide to "soften" the sponge again.

6+7) It might be like you said, the water cannot re-enter the small spaces in the sponge once it is dried. For example, water is trapped between the metals as the sponge is formed, but it's not thermodynamically favorable but rather a "kinetic product" of the reaction. Thus its "hydration" is irreversible. As for why it is softer when wet, that seems to be more of a materials science problem, but I suspect it was something to do with water separating the strands of metals, such that when the water is removed the strands just rub against each other and crack under friction.

Questions 5, 6 and 7.
When you form the lead sponge under water, perhaps some water molecules are wetting the material and forming a layer between neighboring lead crystals. The reason it wobbles like jelly under water could be because of the low attractive forces between wetted crystals. Then, when you dry it, the crystals stick together due to solid-solid friction and becomes a solid. This explains why water cannot get back between the crystals, since they are being held together by stronger attractive forces. In other words, the structure of the foam network changes, but not the foam voids themselves.

1) Possible alloying of sodium and/or potassium impurities with the lead, depressing its melting point much the same way tin would.
2) Very likely high level potassium impurity in original acetate solution that wasn't rinsed off the sponge.
3) Heat catalyzed carbonation of zinc metal forming pyrophoric ZnCO3 which has a very high melting point, and likely responsible for the incandesence, coating the lead fines and preventing them from joining. Water interferes with this and creates simple ZnO which does not mix with the lead.
4) Removing zinc would prevent #3 above?
5) Zinc oxidation in air is not reversible, forms ZnO "ceramic" coating
6) Zinc likes to steal O2 from water, so you would have to flash dry the sponge in an inert atmosphere. Any chemically available oxygen will make it brittle. The stealing oxygen from water process is orders of magnitude slower than free air exposure. See also #5.
7) Pretty much? See #6

I think a big part of the heat/melt resistance comes from the network of ultra-fine threads and structures this process creates. It's a lot like how the ceramic tiles on the space shuttles work. The surface area causes it to oxidize or form other compounds super fast.
